I.  INTRODUCTION 
1.  The proposed advisory technical assistance (ADTA) project will implement the reform 
agenda of Loan 2302 Greater Mekong Subregion Kunming–Hai Phong Transport Corridor: Yen 
Vien–Lao Cai Railway Upgrading Project1 in Viet Nam. The Project will rehabilitate and upgrade 
the Yen Vien–Lao Cai railway line to improve connectivity along the Greater Mekong Subregion 
(GMS) Eastern Economic Corridor, comprising northern Viet Nam and Yunnan province of the 
People’s  Republic  of  China  (PRC),  and  will  improve  the  national  transportation  system 
connecting  Hanoi  with  the  north-western  provinces.  The  loan  was  approved  by  the  Asian 
Development Bank (ADB) Board of Directors on 19 December 2006.2 
2.  The reform agenda was identified and agreed with the Government of Viet Nam during 
loan preparation and will supplement the loan Project by assisting Viet Nam Railways (VNR) 
with improving its accounting systems and its railway operations across the border with the 
PRC. This will help improve the sustainability of the railway. At the time of loan preparation it 
was agreed that the ADTA project would be financed by the Government of France through the 
Agence Française de Développement (AFD) but it was not decided whether the ADTA project 
would be administered by ADB or by AFD. The Government of France has since requested 
ADB to administer the technical assistance component. 
II.  ISSUES 
3.  The  present  issues  in  VNR  arise  from  its  historical  legacy  of  central  government 
ownership and operation, where the state invested in and subsidized the railway as a public 
utility with little concern for the quality of services and the economic efficiency and financial 
sustainability of operations. VNR’s organization and operational procedures are being gradually 
modernized  (see  paras.  8–9)  but  a  major  issue  is  VNR’s  accounting  system,  which  is 
decentralized and cash-flow based, reflecting VNR’s heritage as a government department. The 
system does not reflect capital cost and centrally available data lacks the detail required for 
management  and  marketing  to  effectively  adjust  services  to  the  requirements  of  a  rapidly 
growing market economy. As a result, road transport has gained increasing importance, even 
where railway transport is inherently more efficient than road transport, such as the long-
distance transport of bulk commodities and containers. 
A.  The Government’s and ADB’s Strategy 
4.  The transport sector plays an important role in facilitating rapid economic growth in Viet 
Nam and, in turn, this generates increasing demand for transport. Between 1999 and 2005 
transport demand increased by an average of about 10% per annum. The Government gives 
priority to developing the country’s transport infrastructure in step with transport demand, and 
real  expenditure  in  transport  infrastructure  investments  was  12%  per  year  in  fixed  prices 
between 2000 and 2006.3 The Government’s current strategy for the transport sector focuses on 
(i) targeting national and international financial resources and charging users of infrastructure 
where  possible;  (ii) encouraging  private  sector  participation  in  infrastructure  development, 
operation, and maintenance; (iii) promoting safety and environmental sustainability in transport; 
and (iv) promoting the modernization of infrastructure management.

5.  ADB’s  country  strategy  and  program  for  Viet  Nam  (2007–2010)4 and  the  regional 
transport  strategy  for  the  GMS5 both  support  the  objectives  of  the  Government’s  Socio-
Economic Development Plan (SEDP) 2006–2010.6 The overarching objective of ADB’s country 
strategy  is  the  reduction  of  poverty  through  implementation  of  an  economic  development 
strategy that is closely aligned to the SEDP and its targeted outcomes. The regional transport 
strategy emphasizes the importance of the smooth movement of people and goods in an 
economically,  socially,  and  environmentally  sustainable  manner.  The  objective  of  ADB’s 
strategy for the railway sector in Viet Nam is to improve its economic and financial sustainability 
such that it is capable of efficiently and effectively meeting the demands of the rapidly growing 
economy. 
B.  Regional Cooperation 
6.  The SEDP recognizes the importance of regional cooperation and integration in the 
attainment of the Millennium Development Goals and Viet Nam’s own development goals. It 
recognizes that intraregional trade and investments plays an important role in accelerating the 
pace of economic development in Viet Nam, but also notes that border districts and provinces, 
including Lao Cai, are among the poorest in the country and their future development will 
depend on developments in neighboring countries. The SEDP encourages increased cross-
border trade and investment by (i) providing better cross-border infrastructure, (ii) reforming 
customs and administration, and (iii) strengthening and widening Viet Nam’s participation in 
regional cooperation. 
7.  The Project railway line is part of the Kunming–Hai Phong railway line, which forms part 
of the GMS Eastern Economic Corridor. Trade between Yunnan province and Viet Nam has 
grown dramatically in recent years. Total trade across the Lao Cai–Hekou border crossing grew 
by 36% in 2003 and by 51% in 2004, when it reached $366 million. In 2007 trade is expected to 
reach $700 million, and in 2008 $1 billion. The major commodities traded are steel ingots, 
fertilizers, chemicals, gypsum, seafood, vegetables, and fruit. More than 1 million tons of cargo 
passes through the Lao Cai–Hekou border crossing annually. The crossing is a pilot GMS 
Cross-Border  Transport  Agreement  (CBTA)7 border  crossing.  The  CBTA  is  a  multilateral 
agreement between the GMS countries. It facilitates road transport between the GMS countries 
by implementing measures such as (i) streamlined processing at the border; (ii) mutually agreed 
vehicle standards and driver requirements; and (iii) transit procedures that allow freight to be 
inspected at the point of departure and destination only, rather than at the intermediate border 
crossings. When fully implemented, the CBTA will increase the efficiency of cross-border road 
traffic. Similar streamlining of rail traffic is required in order to increase the competitiveness of 
rail transport. 
C.  Railway Reform 
8.  The ADTA project ties in with a wider railway sector reform program that has been 
ongoing since the early 1990s and since 2000 has been provided with technical assistance by

3 
the  Government  of  Germany.  The  railway  sector  reforms  have  gradually  modernized  the 
structure  and  legal  foundation  of  the  railway  subsector,  encompassing  (i) separating 
infrastructure and operations by splitting VNR into VNR Administration (responsible for railway 
infrastructure and regulation) and VNR Corporation (responsible for implementing maintenance 
and traffic; the split was implemented in 1994 and completed in January 1995 when the financial 
accounts of the two entities were separated); (ii) restructuring of VNR Corporation into four 
operations  areas  (traffic,  rolling  stock,  maintenance,  and  services)  in  January  1995; 
(iii) changing the status of VNR Operations to a state-owned corporation thereby separating the 
railway’s business activities from state management in March 2003; (iv) further dividing the 
traffic area into freight and passenger operations in July 2003; and (v) passing of a new Railway 
Law which provides the legal framework for the private sector to invest in and own new railway 
infrastructure, and to operate privately owned trains on the state’s railway network. The law was 
adopted in May 2005 and became effective on 1 January 2006. 
9.  The  ongoing  technical  assistance  from  Germany  is  centered  on  (i) preparing 
implementing regulations for the new Railway Law, (ii) further reorganizing VNR Corporation, 
(iii) implementing  efficient  infrastructure  access  charging,  and  (iv) modernizing  railway 
regulations. The ADTA project will add to this by helping to secure VNR’s financial sustainability 
by (i) modernizing its accounting systems, which will help VNR improve its cost and revenue 
control and its price setting; and (ii) improving cross-border traffic operations to the PRC, which 
will help increase VNR’s revenue base by streamlining and modernizing cross-border railway 
traffic procedures and facilities at the Lao Cai border crossing. The ADTA project is aligned with 
the  Government’s  objectives  of  making  rail  transport  more  competitive  and  financially 
sustainable in order to reduce the burden on state finances and increase the efficiency and 
international competitiveness of the economy. 
III.  THE TECHNICAL ASSISTANCE 
A.  Impact and Outcome 
10.  The loan project supports Viet Nam’s economic development and strengthens regional 
cooperation by physically enabling high capacity, cost effective, and efficient railway services on 
a part of the GMS Eastern Economic Corridor between Lao Cai and Yien Vinh Station in Hanoi. 
The ADTA project will support realizing this in full through two interventions, outlined below. 
11.  Cross-Border Traffic Improvement Study. This intervention will identify a means of 
improving railway traffic facilitation at the Lao Cai–Hekou border by improving cross-border 
procedures and facilities. This would help reduce the barriers to subregional trade, thereby 
supporting  Viet  Nam’s  economic  development  and  at  the  same  time  increasing  VNR’s 
competitiveness, traffic base, and revenue potential. The output of the intervention would be an 
action plan for improving cross-border railway traffic which, when implemented, would contribute 
directly to subregional integration by encouraging trade and improving the railway’s modal 
competitiveness in relation to road transport by reducing the costs and delays for railway traffic 
crossing the border. Long and uncertain cross-border times impart substantial additional costs 
on transport users, and this reduces trade volumes and the attractiveness of railway transport. 
The output of the study will provide the Vietnamese and PRC authorities with the information 
required to optimize the transportation of goods by rail between the two countries. Although the 
intervention will only assess the situation at the Lao Cai border crossing, its general findings and 
recommendations could be applicable to Viet Nam’s second railway border crossing at Dong 
Dang, on the railway line between Hanoi and Nanning in the PRC. 
12.  Financial  Governance  Reform.  This  intervention  will  implement  stronger  financial 
management  accounting  policies,  procedures,  and  internal  controls  in  a  unified  and

4 
computerized  environment  that  provides  seamless  automation  of  financial  management 
databases with real-time or near real-time data links between the various organizational units of 
VNR. Accurate and timely information on the financial position and operating profitability of 
VNR’s various services is required in order to enable VNR to compete effectively in a market-
oriented transport sector, especially since the passing of the new Railway Law which opens 
railway transport to private operators. The intervention is scheduled over 5 years and is divided 
into two phases. Phase 1 develops the new system of accounts in accordance with generally 
accepted accounting principles and implements it in selected parts of VNR, namely in the VNR 
units engaged in operating and maintaining the railway corridor that is being upgraded under the 
Project.  Phase 2  implements  the  new  accounting  system  throughout  VNR.  Phase 1  is 
implemented under this ADTA project and will take 2 years. Phase 2 will be implemented under 
a future project and will take 3 years. ADB will consider supporting phase 2 when phase 1 has 
been successfully completed. 
13.  The outcome of the ADTA project will be (i) recommendations for streamlined railway 
border operations at Lao Cai, thereby improving the attractiveness and efficiency of railway 
transport  between  the  PRC  and  Viet  Nam;  and  (ii)  a  modernized  system  of  financial 
management accounts and internal controls designed in accordance with international best 
practices for financial reporting and control, and implemented and tested on a pilot basis along 
the  investment  project  railway  line.  The  modernized  accounts  system  will  enable  full  cost 
accounting on an accrual basis and will be appropriate for a corporatized railway operating in a 
market-oriented economy. 
B.  Methodology and Key Activities  
14.  To  achieve  the  outcomes  of  the  cross-border  traffic  improvement  study,  the  ADTA 
project will (i) describe railway traffic conditions on the north-south corridor and the physical, 
operational, and procedural causes of disruptions and delays for border-crossing railway traffic; 
(ii) review and analyze existing agreements, regulations, procedures, and documents used for 
exchanges at the border; (iii) analyze the cross-border operations at the Lao Cai–Hekou border 
in comparison with similar operations at five selected border crossings in Europe and Asia, in 
terms of organization, technology, procedures, and institutional structure using strengths and 
weaknesses analysis; (iv) quantify the consequences of these constraints in terms of additional 
costs  for  the  railways  and  for  transport  users;  (v) recommend  physical,  operational,  and 
procedural improvements that would reduce these costs; and (vi) prepare an action plan for 
implementing the recommendations, which may incorporate investments in equipment and other 
physical  means  at  Lao  Cai  to  be  financed  under  the  Project  or  from  other  sources,  and 
proposed  reforms  to  be  undertaken  by  the  railways  or  by  other  Government  or  private 
institutions in Viet Nam and the PRC. 
15.  To achieve the outcomes of the financial governance reform intervention the ADTA 
project will (i) review the organization of VNR from a financial management perspective and 
within the context of the new Railway Law; (ii) conduct a management audit of VNR; (iii) review 
the system of accounting, financial planning, and budget preparation, control, and execution, 
and make recommendations for improvement; (iv) review internal audit systems, if any, and 
make recommendations for improvement; (v) review independent external auditing and make 
recommendations for improvement; (vi) design and develop a management accounting system 
appropriate to the needs of VNR in a market economy and design data networks and databases 
that  would  enable  frequent  but  not  necessarily  real-time  replication  between  a  centralized 
accounts database at VNR and decentralized accounts databases at VNR subsidiaries using 
inexpensive off-the-shelf components and software; (vii) design and implement training for VNR 
staff; and (viii) assist VNR staff with implementing the new system on a pilot basis in the VNR

5 
subsidiaries that operate on the investment project railway line. Outline terms of reference for 
consultants for both interventions are in Appendix 2. 
C.  Cost and Financing 
16.  The total cost of the ADTA project is estimated at $1.1 million equivalent, and will be 
financed  on  a  grant  basis  by  the  Government  of  France  through  AFD8 in  the  amount  of 
€700,000,(currently equivalent to $980,000) and administered by ADB. The Government of Viet 
Nam will finance the remaining $120,000 equivalent. The detailed cost estimates and financing 
plan is in Appendix 3. 
D.  Implementation Arrangements 
17.  VNR will be the Executing Agency and will implement the project through its Railway 
Project  Management  Unit  (RPMU).  VNR  will  appoint  counterpart  staff  from  its  accounts 
department and other associated units, and from Lao Cai, to work with the ADTA project 
consultants during implementation. It will also establish a steering committee for the ADTA 
project with representatives from relevant ministries and departments in VNR. The steering 
committee  will  be  headed  by  a  deputy  director  general.  VNR  and  the  RPMU  have  prior 
experience with implementation of internationally funded projects, including the ongoing project 
funded by ADB (see para 1) and projects funded by the governments of the PRC, France, and 
Japan. The RPMU has the resources required to effectively manage the ADTA project.  
18.  An individual international consultant with expertise in cross-border traffic and trade 
facilitation will be recruited by ADB for 6 person-months to undertake the cross-border traffic 
improvement study. An international consulting firm, in cooperation with a local consulting firm, 
will be engaged by ADB to implement the financial governance reform. A total of about 15 
person-months of international consultancy services and about 36 person-months of national 
consultancy services are envisaged. The ADTA project is scheduled for initiation in May 2008 
with completion in April 2010. Outline terms of reference for consultants are in Appendix 2. All 
consultants will be engaged in accordance with ADB’s Guidelines on the Use of Consultants 
(2007, as amended from time to time). 
19.  Equipment for the ADTA project, encompassing software and equipment for pilot testing 
of the system, will be procured in accordance with ADB’s Procurement Guidelines (2007, as 
amended  from  time  to  time),  and  will  be  turned  over  to  VNR  upon  Project  completion  in 
accordance  with  ADB’s  procedures.  The  ADTA  project  includes  training  of  VNR  staff  and 
orientation of VNR management and local officials in Lao Cai and Hekou through workshops 
and seminars. 
IV.  THE PRESIDENT'S DECISION  
20.  The President, acting under the authority delegated by the Board, has approved ADB 
administering technical assistance not exceeding the equivalent of $980,000 to the Government 
of Viet Nam to be financed on a grant basis by the Government of France for Strengthening 
Operations and Business Processes in Viet Nam Railways, and hereby reports this action to the 
Board.

Appendix 2  7 
OUTLINE TERMS OF REFERENCE FOR CONSULTANTS 
 
A.  INTERVENTION  1:  IMPROVING  FACILITATION  OF  RAILWAY  TRAFFIC  AT  THE 
LAO CAI BORDER CROSSING 
1.  Scope and Objective 
1.  The  proposed  study  is  aimed  at  providing  Vietnamese  authorities,  as  well  as  their 
counterparts  in  the  People’s  Republic  of  China  (PRC),  with  the  means  and  information 
necessary to make rational decisions on how to optimize the transport of goods by rail between 
the two countries. The study will address the situation at the Lao Cai–Hekou border crossing, 
but the lessons may be adapted for use on the other Viet Nam–PRC rail border at Dong-Dang. 
The findings of the study will also contribute to future bilateral exchanges between the PRC and 
Viet Nam on rail policies. 
2.  The  study  aims  to  identify  bottlenecks  and  recommend  mitigation  measures.  It 
encompasses  two  tasks:  (i) review  of  the  existing  situation  at  the  Lao  Cai–Hekou  border 
crossing  and  determination  of  the  causes  of  delay,  covering  physical,  administrative  and 
institutional  processes  and  constraints;  and  (ii) analysis  and  preparation  of  proposals  for 
improvements and a master plan for implementation. 
2.  Tasks 
a.  Review of the Situation at the Lao Cai–Hekou Border Crossing 
3.  The review will take place on both sides of the border and will encompass the following.  
(i)  Describe the traffic conditions and disruptions currently experienced at the border 
crossing, not only for railway traffic but also for road traffic insofar as road traffic 
complements or competes with railway traffic. The analysis will cover passenger 
as well as cargo traffic with particular focus on container and bulk traffic. 
(ii)  Quantify the consequences of these constraints in terms of loss of time and 
additional costs for the railways and for transport users. 
(iii)  Review and analyze the existing agreements, regulations, documents necessary 
for exchanges at the border (including the 1992 cross-border agreement), and 
other relevant protocols, laws, or rules relating to working rights in both countries 
with a view to identifying their (a) status, (b) level (national or local), (c) dates of 
enforcement  and  expiry,  and  (d)  subject  matter  (e.g.,  trade,  transport,  and 
working rights for drivers). In relation to transport regulations, describe document 
requirements and current controls on import and export of goods. 
(iv)  Identify the main causes of traffic disruption including (a) physical causes, such 
as  the  existence  of  several  points  for  customs  and  unloading  of  freight 
(consideration will be given to the construction of a container yard 1 kilometer 
south of the current Lao Cai station); and (b) institutional and administrative 
causes,  such  as  border-crossing  formalities  and  inspections  for  freight  and 
passengers, restrictions on entry of transport units, and technical standards for 
vehicles. 
(v)  Identify ongoing processes to facilitate transit at the border, including the GMS 
Cross-Border Transport Agreement dealing with road traffic.  
(vi)  Identify any other contributing problems.

8  Appendix 2 
b.  Analysis, Recommendations, and Master plan Preparation  
4.  This task will encompass the following. 
(i)  Propose appropriate measures to facilitate trade including (a) institutional and 
administrative  measures;  (b) improved  procedures  and  organization  of  work, 
including transshipment from road to rail at the border; and (c) physical measures, 
including communications systems. The analysis should include review of the 
issues that would arise if the railway line in the PRC is upgraded to standard 
gauge and investigate the scope for private sector involvement in freight handling 
such as container handling and stuffing and unstuffing at Lao Cai. 
(ii)  For each of the above measures, describe (a) how they will be implemented, (b) 
specific actions required and milestones, and (c) the consequences for each 
country and the combined effect for both countries. 
(iii)  Propose at least three scenarios, each combining one or more of the measures 
identified in (i), and assess the combined impact of the scenario on travel time 
and cost to the railways and the transport users.  
(iv)  For  the  recommended  and  approved  scenario,  prepare  a  master  plan  for 
implementation providing (a) terms of reference, (b) a budget and recommended 
sources of financing, (c) the implementing parties and their responsibilities, (d) 
the  list  of  steps  to  be  taken  to  complete  the  intervention,  and  (e)  an 
implementation schedule . 
3.  Personnel Requirements 
5.  A  consultant  with  experience  in  transport,  cross-border  traffic,  trade  facilitation, 
international customs, and cross-border agreements will be recruited for 6 person-months. The 
candidate  will  carry  out  desk  research  and  fieldwork  and  will  meet  with  relevant  national 
authorities. Viet Nam Railways will support the consultant to collect data, arrange interviews 
with railway, customs, and local government personnel in Viet Nam, and assist in arranging 
internal travel. 
4.  Deliverables 
6.  A report will be prepared after completion of the review and submitted to VNR, ADB, and 
the Agence Française de Développement. This report will provide initial findings and contain 
recommendations on conducting the analysis and prepare recommendations and the master 
plan.  In  the  analysis  phase  a  more  in-depth  evaluation  of  the  findings  will  be  made  and 
agreements reached on how to implement appropriate measures. These will be described in 
detail in a final report submitted after completion of the master plan. 
7.  Depending  on  the  outcome  of  the  review,  deliverables  would  be  (i) proposals  for 
reorganizing  operations,  modernizing  procedures,  and  wider  involvement  of  private  sector 
operators; and (ii) sketch designs or draft specifications for physical improvements which will be 
an input into detailed design and implementation under the investment project or in separate 
projects. 
5.  Schedule 
8.  The study is expected to take 5 months, starting in March 2008.

Appendix 2  9 
B.  INTERVENTION 2: FINANCIAL GOVERNANCE REFORM PROGRAM FOR VIETNAM 
RAILWAYS 
1.  Scope and Outcomes 
9.  The components will include (i) analyzing the present financial management and control 
organization and its system of accounts; (ii) designing an enhanced financial management 
system in a semi-automated environment congruent to the organizational structure of VNR; (iii) 
implementing the proposed system on a pilot basis; and (iv) training. The outputs of the financial 
management  analysis  component  will  include  a  road  map  for  the  intervention,  including 
recommendations  on  (i)  organizational  structure  (including  internal  audit),  and  (ii)  human 
resource competencies and skills required within the financial accounting and internal audit and 
control  units  of  VNR.  The  design  and  implementation  components  will  support  VNR  staff 
through the pilot implementation of the enhanced financial and managerial accounting system. 
They will include reevaluating the assets and liabilities of the companies, including reevaluating 
fixed  assets  and  inventories,  and  reviewing  the  contingent  accounts,  if  any.  The  training 
component will be an underlying capacity-building program of the ADTA project. 
10.  The outcome will be an improved system of financial management accounts and internal 
control designed in accordance with international good practice standards of financial reporting 
and control as appropriate for a railway operating in a market-oriented economy, implemented 
on a pilot basis. It is expected that phase 1 will cost an estimated $600,000 and will be 
implemented over a period of 18 months. Consultancy services will be provided by a firm 
(preferably  an  association  between  an  international  accounting  and  auditing  firm  and  a 
Vietnamese accounting and auditing firm). It will require 15 person-months of international 
consultants and 36 person-months of national consultants.  
2.  Tasks 
11.  The consulting firm will undertake the following tasks. 
(i)  Review  the  organization  of  VNR  with  regard  to  its  relationships  with  its 
subsidiaries and the separation of infrastructure from operations from a financial 
management perspective and within the context of the new Railway Law and its 
implementing decrees. 
(ii)  Conduct a management audit of VNR, including a review of the effectiveness of 
its financial organization with regard to business units, profit centers, and cost 
centers. 
(iii)  Review the system of control over cash receipts and disbursements, accounts 
receivables  and  payables,  and  fixed  assets  and  inventories  (including  the 
existence  of  registers, supporting documentation,  and  control  accounts),  and 
reconcile the book values with the control accounts in the general ledger. 
(iv)  Evaluate assets and obligations, such as fixed assets, inventories, and liabilities 
(including contingent liabilities) to ascertain whether the book values are realistic. 
(v)  Review the system of financial planning and budget preparation, control, and 
execution. 
(vi)  Review  internal  audit  activities,  if  any,  and  make  recommendations  for  the 
establishment of regular internal audits and controls. 
(vii)  Review the system of independent external monitoring controls, such as activities 
of the external auditors and state auditors, audits of financial statements, and 
audit reports for public disclosure.

10  Appendix 2 
(viii)  Prepare  recommendations  for  the  introduction  of  appropriate  good-practice 
systems in items (i) to (vii). 
(ix)  Develop a management accounting system appropriate to the needs of VNR in a 
market  economy,  establish  local-area  and  wide-area  network  connections 
enabling frequent but not necessarily real-time replication between a centralized 
accounts  database  at  VNR  and  decentralized  accounts  databases  at  VNR 
subsidiaries  using  inexpensive  off-the-shelf  components  and  software,  and 
design and implement training programs for staff. The system will reflect the 
structure of VNR. 
(x)  In the pilot implementation phase, (a) assist VNR staff to set up the approved 
financial and management accounting system, (b) establish revenue and cost 
center reporting systems, and (c) engage in extensive consultation with VNR, the 
Ministry  of  Transport,  and  other  government  agencies  before  finalizing  the 
financial management system. 
3.  Personnel Requirements 
a.  International Accounting Specialist and Team Leader (12 person-months, 
intermittent) 
12.  The  senior  financial  management  specialist  must  have  experience  in  carrying  out 
management  and  financial  audits.  He  or  she  must  have  a  professional  designation  as  a 
chartered accountant or its equivalent and must have a demonstrated successful track record of 
designing and developing financial management systems in an automated environment in the 
railway sector. The specialist should have at least 15 years’ experience, at least 10 years of 
which should be appropriate international experience, preferably in a developing economy. He 
or she will be the team leader for the ADTA project and will provide not only the technical 
expertise but also the project management and supervisory skills required to manage a team of 
international and national experts. The specialist should be proficient in database software 
systems. 
b.  International Automation Specialist (3 person-months, intermittent) 
13.  The international automation specialist must have proven experience in designing and 
implementing financial management and database systems, preferably for the railway sector. 
He or she should have knowledge of the available cost-effective tools which can be used to 
further the automation efforts in VNR. He or she will provide direct technical support to the team 
leader with regard to automation aspects of the project. Once the system is put in place, the 
specialist will provide training to VNR staff on its use. 
c.  National Accounting and Auditing Specialists (2 positions, 24 person-
months combined, intermittent) 
14.  The national accounting and auditing specialists should be graduates in accounting 
and/or auditing, with at least 5 years’ experience. They should be proficient in English and 
preferably have work experience in international organizations. They should be proficient in 
software systems. 
d.  National Automation Specialist (12 person-months, intermittent) 
15.  The national automation specialist must possess the ability to customize and deploy off-
the-shelf software to meet the specific management information system needs of VNR. He or

Appendix 2  11 
she should have a proven record of producing quality programs and/or systems for service 
companies  (preferably  in  the  transport  sector).  He  or  she  will  support  the  work  of  the 
international automation specialist, should be proficient in English, and preferably have worked 
in an international organization.  
4.  Deliverables 
16.  The deliverables of the intervention are as follows. 
(i)  An  assessment  of  the  existing  management  accounting  system,  financial 
accounts, and organization of VNR, and a time-bound action plan for financial 
governance reform,  sequencing the activities and interdependencies and the 
estimated cost of carrying out the proposals contained in the plan. 
(ii)  An  organizational  plan  appropriate  to  an  effective  management  information 
system, including draft terms of reference and job descriptions for the financial 
accounting, internal audit, and control departments, and their staff. If required, 
advisory  assistance  will  be  provided  to  VNR  in  the  realignment  of  certain 
departments within VNR in order to implement the system. 
(iii)  Development  and  implementation  on  a  pilot  basis  of  an  enhanced  financial 
control and management system, and a training program, including workshops to 
create awareness of the new financial management system, in the operational 
and support units in VNR. A diagnosis of the accounting and finance skills of 
VNR staff will be carried out and will form the baseline indicators by which the 
effectiveness of the training program will be assessed by the end of the ADTA 
project. 
(iv)  Reports as follows: (a) an inception report within 1 month from fielding of the 
consultant  team,  outlining  its  initial  diagnosis,  its  proposed  approach  to  the 
project, and a schedule of activity for the ADTA project; (b) semi-annual progress 
reports  during  the  duration  of  the  project;  (c)  a  draft  final  completion  report 
circulated 1.5 months prior to end of the project; and (d) a final completion report 
issued at end of the project. All reports should be discussed in consultation with 
VNR and ADB. 
5.  Viet Nam Railways Commitments 
17.  VNR will establish a finance working group of about 10 full-time VNR employees who will 
participate fully and actively in the process of developing and implementing the Project. The 
members of the finance working group will be representatives of the departments involved in the 
financial  management  system.  After  having  been  involved  in  the  planning  and  conceptual 
process, these staff members will be in a position to implement the new system. The finance 
working group will be headed by a senior VNR staff member who will be able to provide 
information and discuss problems directly with VNR management. This group should also be 
able to carry out detailed assignments—such as listing fixed assets and taking inventory—and 
be able to answer specific questions relating to railway matters. The cost of the finance working 
group (such as remuneration of its members) will be borne by VNR. VNR will make clean, air-
conditioned, furnished office accommodation (with internet and communication facilities), and 
printing and photocopying facilities available to the consultants for the duration of the Project. It 
will also provide local land transport (one vehicle full-time) free of charge. 
6.  Schedule 
18.  The study is expected to take 20 months, starting in May 2008.
